title:
Role of symmetry in the correlated orientational disordered phase of
  entropic crystals
authors: Sumitava Kundu, Kaustav Chakraborty, Avisek Das
abstract:
The crystalline solids with lack of orientational ordering serve the purpose
of studying the disordered systems with many fundamental applications in
contemporary research. Despite the orientational disorder, the constituent
particles sometime follow some conserved laws or correlation while maintaining
the translational order depicted by the crystal structure. Such phase is called
``correlated orientational disordered'' phase in the crystal. Polyhedral
particles in the presence of hard-core interaction provide a great opportunity
to study the orientational order and disorder in entropy driven self-assembly.
We report the computational evidence of the role of symmetry of the polyhedral
particles and cubic crystalline structures exhibiting the correlated disordered
phases, which are obtained from the simulations of single-component systems.
The point groups of the particle and crystal structure appear to be directly
connected with the existence of multiple unique orientations satisfying a few
other orientational features. In this phase, the systems exhibit
orientationally frozen states at sufficiently higher packing fractions and
discrete orientational hopping at comparatively lower ones while all the
signatures of the correlation are preserved. This symmetry relationship appears
to control all the aspects of orientational correlation in the crystalline
solids which might be useful to draw fundamental insights about the disordered
phases with orientational correlation as well as designing the disorder in the
crystals.
